hints.content: From the Fundamental Theorem of Algebra, we know that a polynomial of degree $6$ has six roots.  The roots are real, or complex and non-real (which we'll just refer to as complex).   Complex roots must occur in pairs.

Let's look at the graph of the polynomial $\pink{p(x)}$.  We see that it has $5$ $x$-intercepts.  Since complex roots occur in pairs, there must be $6$ real roots.  Similarly, $\blue{r(x)}$ has $6$ distinct $x$-intercepts, so it has $6$ real roots.  

Since $\green{q(x)}$ does not cross the $x$-axis, it has $6$ complex  roots.

We have:

* $p(x)$ and $r(x)$ have $6$ real roots.

*  $q(x)$ has $6$ complex  roots.

question.content:
Three polynomials of degree $6$ are shown on the graph below.

**Match each of the polynomials to the appropriate description of its roots.**

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/35c279ed3c0f29f276e188c3d6b6fcde8701b192.png)

[[â˜ƒ categorizer 1]]

categories: Four real roots, two complex  roots
